title: Patterns of Evidence: Journey to Mount Sinai II
description: Have Exodus Explorers found the evidence for Mount Sinai? Filmmaker Timothy Mahoney completes his 20-year search for the true location of the mountain where God gave the ten commandments. In the conclusion of a two-part series, Mahoney uses the Mount Sinai Scorecard to investigate the final three of the six most popular locations proposed for Mount Sinai. Could Mount Sinai actually be Har Karkom, in Israel's Negev desert, strewn with thousands of pieces of rock art? Might the mountain be at one of two locations in Saudi Arabia? Mt. Bedr, a recently active volcano, or Jabal al Lawz where explorers claim abundant evidence matches the events of the Exodus? See an amazing pattern of evidence and decide for yourself the mountain where Moses and the Israelites met and worshiped God.

title: Oregonda
description: Star Force Galactic Command is battling to protect earth's solar system from the ruthless Draconian when intel is obtained of a bio-weapon that could destroy humanity. Despite ongoing repairs, the spacecraft Oregonda must leave port from the command ship Nastron and travel into enemy territory to retrieve evidence of the weapons existence before it's too late. Piloted by the tenacious Captain Leila Collins (Leanne Johnson) and commanded by headstrong Major Remus Hughes (Eric Shook) the Oregonda embarks on a reconnaissance mission of action, adventure and intrigue in order to turn the war and save the world.

characteristics.Producer:: Eric Shook, Leanne Johnson

title: Eric Clapton: Across 24 Nights
description: In 1990 and in 1991 Eric Clapton played 24 nights at the Royal Albert Hall performing with different line-ups and sets featuring Blues, Rock, and a full Orchestra. The performances have become legendary to Eric Clapton fans. Over thirty years later this film, edited from the original footage and completely remastered in Dolby Surround Sound, captures for the first time the definitive performances across all the sets over both years. The film features 17 hits from across his repertoires showing Clapton at his most exhilarating, collaborating with top musicians.

characteristics.Producer:: Peter Worsley
Priyanka Dutt

title: Pichaikkaran 2
description: A business tycoon named Vijay Gurumoorthy is assassinated by a goon called Satya.

characteristics.Producer:: Fathima Vijay Antony
characteristics.Writer:: Paul Antony, Vijay Antony, K. Palani

title: Fast X
description: Over many missions and against impossible odds, Dom Toretto (Vin Diesel) and his family have outsmarted, out-nerved and outdriven every foe in their path. Now, they confront the most lethal opponent they've ever faced: A terrifying threat emerging from the shadows of the past who's fueled by blood revenge, and who is determined to shatter this family and destroy everything--and everyone--that Dom loves, forever.

characteristics.Rating:: PG-13 (Intense Sequences of Violence|Action|Language|Some Suggestive Material)
characteristics.Producer:: Neal H. Moritz, Vin Diesel, Justin Lin, Jeff Kirschenbaum, Samantha Vincent
characteristics.Production Co:: Original Film, Perfect Storm Entertainment, One Race Films

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Fast X hits all the expected (and now familiar) tropes and beats, but this being the first in a multi-movie story, it is ultimately a little underwhelming… but regardless, we will all return for the next chapter like the dutiful cult members we are.

reviews.name: Candice McMillan
reviews.message: [Jason Momoa] is the glorious future of the Fast franchise, and we are furious it took this long for his debut.

reviews.name: Miles Surrey
reviews.message: The increasingly predictable, self-referential nature of the storytelling makes every subsequent film feel like a parody of itself—the cinematic equivalent of drifting around in circles.

reviews.name: Vincent Mancini
reviews.message: Discount action movie slurry.

reviews.name: Eddie Harrison
reviews.message: …the cheerful gang-show mentality still invests Fast and Furious franchise entries with an easy-going, undemanding guilty-pleasure charm, but it’s wearing a little thin by movie ten…

reviews.name: Harris Dang
reviews.message: Even with the lack of family togetherness, resolve and behind-the-scenes faults, Fast X delivers exactly what fans would expect in terms of action and absurdity while surprising us with an entertainingly over-the-top Jason Momoa performance.

reviews.name: Kip Mooney
reviews.message: Just when I thought this series was out of gas, Fast X hit the nitrous boost.

reviews.name: Abby Olcese
reviews.message: Much of Fast X is lots of fun, and the dynamics between the characters are as satisfying as ever

reviews.name: Micheal Compton
reviews.message: Is Fast X a good movie? Probably not. But is it a good time, that delivers exactly what the audience wants? Most definitely.

reviews.name: Cody Leach
reviews.message: Fast X continues to deliver big, loud & dumb entertainment but it's diminishing returns with a forced and frustrating cliffhanger. Momoa's villain is a blast while the script, dialogue, and soap opera drama is among the weakest of the franchise.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: The 10th official movie in this wildly popular franchise -- the first of a two-parter -- has the same, now-somewhat-tired formula: travel, stunts, fights, explosions, crashes, "family" talk, repeat.

reviews.name: Lupe Rodriguez Haas
reviews.message: The tenth installment is more of the same gravity-defying stunts and laughable dialogue but Jason Momoa fuels the action with humor. The script is also filled with fun moments that poke fun at the "familia" and the ridiculous car stunts.

reviews.name: Dana Han-Klein
reviews.message: It is 3 different movies at once. All lacking in logic, plot, and coherent character development. Yet somehow still a campy fun ride. Momoa makes for a flamboyant injection of life. Action wise the set pieces fail to meet the bar set by previous entries.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: We are at the point where we have to question what is going on here. Fast X is an empty experience and one of the worst entries in a spectacular franchise.

reviews.name: Kevin Carr
reviews.message: This is by far the most ridiculous installment in the Fast & Furious franchise, and remember they drove a car into space in the last one.

reviews.name: Nestor Bentancor
reviews.message: It starts firing on all cylinders, but it's tiring mechanics take us along winding roads, better traveled in the past. A well-oiled amusement park ride in its day, the franchise is increasingly feeling like a creaking carousel. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: Pigs are flying, hell has frozen over, and monkeys are flying out of Wayne Campbell’s butt, because they finally made one of these that I enjoyed.

reviews.name: Theolin Tembo
reviews.message: Fast X delivers on upping the ante with the explosions and intricate fight choreography that will leave you pumped up. Charmingly, though, where the film hooks you most is the heart and love of family.

reviews.name: Fico Cangiano
reviews.message: A tad better than the previous film, yet still one of the weakest entries of the whole franchise. Come for more absurd, silly action hijinks, stay for Jason Momoa's flashy, bonkers Dante Reyes - best villain of the series. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Juanma Fernández París
reviews.message: Its focus on shooting up adrenaline levels and on an impressive execution of the action, this time around directed by Louis Leterrier, is nullified by a script that doesn't seek anything new, just recycles and upsizes. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Liz Shannon Miller
reviews.message: The franchise hasn’t quite yet run out of ways to combine cars, guns, planes, and explosions… but perhaps it’s good that there are maybe only two films left until the franchise officially “ends.”

reviews.name: Ryan Syrek
reviews.message: “Fast X” is dumb, ugly, and awkward. It is goofy in the bad way, not goofy in the awesome way or goofy in the “Gawrsh!” way, either of which would have been better.

reviews.name: Lisa Johnson Mandell
reviews.message: When you stage a car chase scene in the beginning that involves a flaming giant bowling ball bomb smashing through Rome, it's exhausting trying to sustain that type of velocity through the entire film. But Jason Momoa's fabulous villain makes it worth it.

reviews.name: Piers Marchant
reviews.message: Dom -- and the film -- are so relentless with the notion of whatever family means, it all begins to feel like so much sentimentalist drivel, a colorfully patterned carpet designed to distract you from all the people losing money at the slot machines.

reviews.name: Brian Viner
reviews.message: ... It’s more like a Vanity Fair party than a movie — yet only a splendid new villain (Jason Momoa) seems to be having any real fun. Luckily, he’s fabulous.

reviews.name: Conor O'Donnell
reviews.message: Fast newcomer Louis Letterier, ever a big-dumb-movie workman, siphons enough goofy energy from some of his previous blockbusters to inject some verve back into this lumbering series.

reviews.name: Damond Fudge
reviews.message: Despite its flaws...I—as a big fan of the entire Fast Saga—still had a lot of fun.

reviews.name: Ricardo Rosado
reviews.message: Fast X isn't just a movie, it's a madman's dream, a celebration of the self-referential blockbuster, and yet, it takes itself ridiculously seriously... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Chris Vognar
reviews.message: It would be OK if Fast X were merely loud and dumb; that much is to be expected. The problem is that it’s also achingly mechanical. It’s all car, no driver.

reviews.name: Christopher Lloyd
reviews.message: Look, you know what you're going to get: high-octane car chases, face-offs and fisticuffs, lots (too much) blather about "family," etc. Jason Momoa livens things up as a quirky, devilish villain, but too many callback moments and cameos.

reviews.name: M.V. Moorhead
reviews.message: What this movie suggests that cars, and human bodies, can do and withstand is recklessly delusional, and to assume that it has no effect on the behavior of real-life drivers raised on movies like this seems naïve.

reviews.name: Sarah Gopaul
reviews.message: Momoa’s villain is deliciously over-the-top as he relishes playing the insane psychopath and delivers the picture’s best moments, singlehandedly raising the movie’s watchability rating.

reviews.name: Susan Kamyab
reviews.message: I think we all expect the movies to be silly and they have always been self-aware of how ridiculous they can be with their impossible stunts. But sadly, "Fast X" just proves that the franchise is running out of gas.

reviews.name: Keith Garlington
reviews.message: The franchise freed itself from the restraints of reality a long time ago. “Fast X” is openly self-aware yet it has an undeniably big heart. And Momoa brings a blithely psychotic energy that you can’t turn away from.

reviews.name: Andy Lea
reviews.message: Nobody watches this series for a coherent story but it’s clearly ridiculous. The screenwriters know it too, peppering the dialogue with self-aware quips.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Even by series standards, the globetrotting plot bridging the set pieces feels uninspired and rudimentary as it funnels toward an obligatory high-stakes final showdown.

reviews.name: John Urbancich
reviews.message: Even with four Oscar winners, furious action rules one more time. (mini review)

reviews.name: Aaron Peterson
reviews.message: Fast X continues what fans have come to expect from the Fast and Furious films, while polishing up this tired ride with a fresh coat of Jason Momoa having an absolute blast.

reviews.name: Alison Willmore
reviews.message: A decent diversion, though watching it feels like sustaining a head injury.

reviews.name: Christopher Cross
reviews.message: Fast X is an idea without direction: fun in the moment, but the lack of closure on any arc and the mishandling of other arcs serve as a reminder that the franchise was always held together by duct tape.

title: Sanctuary
description: Set over the course of one night in a single hotel room, "Sanctuary" tells the story of a dominatrix (Margaret Qualley) and Hal (Christopher Abbott), her wealthy client. About to inherit his late father's position and fortune, Hal tries to end their relationship, but when his attempt to cut ties backfires, disaster ensues.

characteristics.Producer:: Pavel Burian, David Lancaster, Ilya Stewart, Stephanie Wilcox
characteristics.Production Co:: Hype Studios, Mosaic Films, Rumble Films (II), Charades

reviews.name: Laura Clifford
reviews.message: It isn’t until the very final scene that we realize that what director Zachary Wigon and writer Micah Bloomberg have crafted is a perverse romcom, a feature of a film which continually keeps us guessing.

reviews.name: Katie Rife
reviews.message: Writer Micah Bloomberg’s script ingeniously incorporates the movie’s themes into its structure, and Qualley and Abbott—but especially Qualley—playfully keep the audience guessing throughout.

reviews.name: Leo Brady
reviews.message: The final result from Sanctuary is two of the best acting performances of 2023, with a narrative that will spark great conversation, in a sharp portrayal of the many pleasures– or pains–that can happen in a person’s world.

reviews.name: Katie Walsh
reviews.message: All the excellent acting and sumptuous style can’t cover up that the culmination of this tête-à-tête is disappointingly hollow with an ironic bow on top.

reviews.name: Jason Adams
reviews.message: Abbott is real good at this sort of thing, with those bedroom cow-eyes of his, black as tar. Unknowable. Punchable. And Qualley, her current star rising like the sun seen from six inches away, proves a formidable partner.

reviews.name: Bill Newcott
reviews.message: It’s all exhausting fun, tapping into the cerebral circuits of brain teasers like Anthony Shaffer’s Sleuth and David Slade’s Hard Candy.

reviews.name: Mark Jackson
reviews.message: The message--that women have usurped so many traditionally male roles--while not a groundbreaking concept in and of itself, has a particular logic here that's engaging.

reviews.name: Josh Bell
reviews.message: Director Zachary Wigon plays with audience assumptions as he reveals the true dynamic between Hal and Rebecca, and Sanctuary continues to brilliantly defy expectations for its entire runtime.

reviews.name: Travis Hopson
reviews.message: There are plenty of comfortable rom-coms out there, but Sanctuary is a surprisingly beguiling and witty romance for those who like their love stories to need a safe word.

reviews.name: Zoë Rose Bryant
reviews.message: The summer movie season is synonymous with bombastic blockbusters, but "Sanctuary" shows that there are just as many fireworks that can arise from the unfiltered expression of our unruly human feelings

reviews.name: Danielle Solzman
reviews.message: Margaret Qualley and Christopher Abbott never lose our attention as the duo are acting their hearts out in Sanctuary.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: With energetic insight and humor, Sanctuary scrapes and scrapes at these characters and the power dynamics between them.

reviews.name: Jeannette Catsoulis
reviews.message: If you’re someone who regularly bemoans the dearth of movies for adults, then take heart: “Sanctuary” is here for you.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: Bold, provocative, intermittently shocking entertainment. Margaret Qualley is a dynamo.

reviews.name: Darryl Griffiths
reviews.message: In a genre with a wretched habit of churning out regularly tame mediocrity. Sanctuary is a downright thrilling entry, loaded with sex appeal, compelling social commentary and a delicious sense of danger.

reviews.name: Julian Roman
reviews.message: Sanctuary ropes your attention with fascinating power dynamics that titillate and tease sinister developments. Slick filmmaking and beguiling performances sell a potent narrative.

reviews.name: Robert Kojder
reviews.message: Sanctuary is a nonstop exhilarating kinky thrill-ride that dares to keep one-upping itself in abhorrent behavior that one can’t help cheering on; Margaret Qualley and Christopher dominate the screen

reviews.name: Aaron White
reviews.message: Super sexy & psychotic manipulative mind games with a terrific script, score & camerawork make this tight single location thriller a captivating blast. Qualley is so convincingly phenomenal that she had me simultaneously terrified and equally turned on.

reviews.name: Matt Oakes
reviews.message: Qualley’s dominance in 'Sanctuary' is not limited to her character's profession; it's in every scene she graces, every line she delivers, every look she gives.

reviews.name: Brianna Zigler
reviews.message: Sanctuary is exciting and scintillating, a formally impressive and taut erotic thriller that showcases Wigon’s directorial capability and the prowess of the actors under his guidance.

reviews.name: Kurt Loder
reviews.message: We wonder if there’s some sort of kicky sex romp in the offing. In any other movie, maybe. But this is definitely not any other movie.

reviews.name: Greg Nussen
reviews.message: This is a theatrical story told in a purposefully and self-consciously theatrical manner.

reviews.name: Kyle Logan
reviews.message: Seems to want to play it both ways as a genre film; as a thriller that unnerves and arouses its audience and as an unconventional but ultimately heartwarming romantic comedy. In doing so it fails at being great at either. It’s quite good as both.

reviews.name: Rob Thomas
reviews.message: As the balance of power moves back and forth between the two, “Sanctuary” shifts between erotic thriller, pitch-black comedy and, most surprisingly, sweet romance. Which one will end up on top? I’ll never tell.

reviews.name: David Gonzalez
reviews.message: Rich with dominating performances by Christopher Abbott and Margaret Qualley, the film examines power within gender, class, humanity, and relationship dynamics in a delicious fashion. It's a one-night stand all cinephiles should desire.

reviews.name: Hannah Strong
reviews.message: Despite the imperfections within Bloomberg’s screenplay, Abbott and Qualley sell the hell out of it – they possess an easy chemistry that fluctuates between desire, desperation and despisal.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Offbeat, fascinating but uneven love story.

reviews.name: Rachel Ho
reviews.message: Wigon does a tremendous job with a bare premise and stripped-down production.

reviews.name: Amanda the Jedi
reviews.message: Viewers will feel just as mentally twisted as Abbott's character as Qualley's winds through her desires and intentions - and that's the thrill of Sanctuary. Each moment breaking away the barriers of what's real and what's orchestrated.

reviews.name: Rendy Jones
reviews.message: He was an heir. She was a dom. Can I make it any more obvious?

reviews.name: Jeffrey Zhang
reviews.message: Explores the whirlwind disintegration of a relationship that slowly chips away at the barriers between fantasy and reality, class and control.

reviews.name: Piers Marchant
reviews.message: The script, from Micah Bloomberg, is sharp and salty as a broken pretzel rod; and the soundtrack, from composer Ariel Marx, ranging from atonal blurts, to driving low-end strings, connects all the disparate pieces perfectly.

reviews.name: Stephen Silver
reviews.message: The story of a man, a woman, and a dominant/submissive relationship in which we’re meant to question what’s part of the game and what isn’t, is one of the most purely enjoyable films of the season.

reviews.name: Kevin L. Lee
reviews.message: Christopher Abbott and Margaret Qualley sizzle on screen together. They keep Sanctuary fun, suspenseful, and arousing, down to the perfectly delivered last line.

reviews.name: Jesse Catherine Webber
reviews.message: If Sanctuary feels like an exercise at times, it’s one that remains consistently compelling and ultimately moving throughout its machinations.

reviews.name: Dan Bayer
reviews.message: [Margaret Qualley and Christopher Abbott are] two of the most watchable actors of their generation, but they step up their games considerably for this, bringing scorching charisma and immense talent to the film.

reviews.name: Nick Schager
reviews.message: There’s no way to get a total read on what Qualley’s protagonist is up to, which turns out to be the primary thrill of this snapshot of personal, professional, and class warfare.

reviews.name: Amy Nicholson
reviews.message: The film has the confidence and generosity to allow the audience to ask its own questions before it makes its first (of many) giddily upending reveals.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: What begins as a feminist-leaning story transforms into one that’s more off-putting and problematic.

reviews.name: David Ehrlich
reviews.message: What makes Sanctuary such a salaciously enjoyable slice of snack-sized fun is how it argues that some people have more to give than they would ever know without the right person to take it from them.

title: Master Gardener
description: Directed by Academy Award® nominee Paul Schrader based on his original screenplay, MASTER GARDENER follows Narvel Roth (award-winner Joel Edgerton), the meticulous horticulturist of Gracewood Gardens. He is as much devoted to tending the grounds of this beautiful and historic estate, to pandering to his employer, the wealthy dowager Mrs. Haverhill (three-time Academy Award® nominee Sigourney Weaver). When Mrs. Haverhill demands that he take on her wayward and troubled great-niece Maya (Quintessa Swindell) as a new apprentice, chaos enters Narvel's spartan existence, unlocking dark secrets from a buried violent past that threaten them all.

characteristics.Producer:: David Gonzales, Amanda Crittenden, Scott LaStaiti
characteristics.Production Co:: Curmudgeon Films, Kojo Studios, Ottocento Films

reviews.name: David Fear
reviews.message: Though this story of a stoic groundskeeper doesn't have the heft of Schrader's masterpiece First Reformed or his restless royal flush The Card Counter, it's still the sort of burrowing, brow-furrowing drama that forces you to reckon with big questions.

reviews.name: Anne Brodie
reviews.message: chilling study of a man transformed by the deep art of gardening. he’s put everything he has into Gracewood Gardens.  The film makes a huge U-turn but all roads lead back to Gracewood. Interesting, provocative, odd and dark, typical of Schrader.

reviews.name: Jeffrey M. Anderson
reviews.message: Paul Schrader's drama touches on White supremacy in a fascinating yet troubling way, but its balancing act of tenderness and kindness -- and the way it lingers on the beauty of flora -- wins the day.

reviews.name: David Sims
reviews.message: Is Schrader becoming a softie in his advancing age? Maybe, but I think Master Gardener’s sensitivity is provocative in and of itself, daring the audience to forgive a man whose past is steeped in profound evil.

reviews.name: David Sexton
reviews.message: This film is not just “a nasty gumbo”, as Schrader says proudly, and preposterous -- but also pretty much inexcusable. And yet I have to say that I loved it for being so distinct in its texture, so clearly part of a lifetime’s work.

reviews.name: Ray Pride
reviews.message: A trilogy of terroir; the dirt of earth, the filth of Abu Ghraib, the garden of inherited wealth that pretends to the Edenic/
reviews.full_review: Trilogy of terroir: Paul Schrader and the percolating solitary https://www.newcityfilm.com/2023/05/19/sent-out-of-the-garden-a-review-of-paul-schraders-master-gardener/

reviews.name: James Verniere
reviews.message: Another Bressonian study of a troubled and isolated man from Schrader.

reviews.name: Rob Thomas
reviews.message: Despite some good performances and a slightly more hopeful tone, “Gardener” offers diminishing returns on a well-traveled theme.

reviews.name: Eric Marchen
reviews.message: Nobody does what Schrader has methodically cultivated quite as well, which is to craft a stripped down examination of one man’s tormented soul spilling over diary pages in a darkly lit room. It’s intoxicating to behold.

reviews.name: Sumner Forbes
reviews.message: A portrait of a very broken man.

reviews.name: Glenn Kenny
reviews.message: A terrifically emotional film.

reviews.name: Jason Adams
reviews.message: A gentility and honest-to-goodness sweetness is suddenly Schrader’s most disarming characteristic.

reviews.name: Oscar Goff
reviews.message: Master Gardener is pretty damn far from feel-good entertainment in the Frank Capra vein, but it suggests that, even in a world as bleak as Schrader’s, self-destruction is not necessarily preordained.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Despite some intriguing character dynamics, the film’s muted emotions and muddled allegory keep this morality tale in the weeds.

reviews.name: Hoai-Tran Bui
reviews.message: There is something cathartic about a filmmaker whose entire ethos has been defined by discontent finally embracing something that looks eerily like contentment.

reviews.name: Daniel Goodwin
reviews.message: A powerful, provocative return-to-form for Schrader, and one that should be revered alongside his past masterpieces.

reviews.name: Adam Kempenaar
reviews.message: “Gardener” concludes a trilogy in which the protagonists have gotten increasingly unsympathetic and decreasingly redeemable, yet the sly, subversive Schrader also made this third piece the most hopeful.

reviews.name: Anthony Lane
reviews.message: It’s almost as if the movie were following the blueprint of a moral scheme, like the layout of a herbaceous border, and plausibility be damned.

reviews.name: Stephanie Zacharek
reviews.message: The less you know about Master Gardener going in, the better: tracing the trail of these characters’ secrets is part of the thrill. But it’s compelling for other reasons too.

reviews.name: Peter Travers
reviews.message: With its pokey pace broken by bursts of violence and racial tension, the end of Paul Schrader’s man-in-a-room trilogy falls short of the master’s peak. But this mesmerizer is  the work of a true film artist striving to connect his tortured soul to ours.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: You couldn't render MASTER GARDENER riper for ill-conceived social commentary if you tried. Because he doesn't even try to approach the psychology of what he's created. It's literally all for kicks.

reviews.name: Alistair Ryder
reviews.message: Dramatic character studies of supposedly reformed Nazis are hardly novel  and even in Schrader's hands, this complicated figure remains one-dimensional.

reviews.name: Odie Henderson
reviews.message: An excruciatingly slow white-savior narrative that aims to provoke yet does nothing but bore.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: Master Gardener becomes too tangled in its preachy nature to live up to the standard of his recent films.

reviews.name: Oliver Weir
reviews.message: Schrader's pryings into what is most fragile and explosive in the male ego, and his bold stagings of the violent interface between belief and rationality, don't sting or shock like they used to. Instead, they have lapsed into a kind of staid pastiche.

reviews.name: Kyle Smith
reviews.message: Though Master Gardener may not be as effective as either The Card Counter or First Reformed... it burnishes [Paul Schrader's] reputation as a great American portraitist.

reviews.name: Adam Graham
reviews.message: [Schrader ] eventually falls into a trap of male fantasy which betrays his characters' truths.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Edgerton gives one of his most compact and introverted performances as this man "saved" by "manure" and what can grow in it

reviews.name: Andrew Parker
reviews.message: It’s a lesser work from Schrader, but far from his worst and bearing some fruit by the end.

reviews.name: Prabhjot Bains
reviews.message: Master Gardener never delivers on its promise, tilling its grounds with great purpose and vision but neglecting to nourish it to fruition.

reviews.name: Michael J. Casey
reviews.message: The charge here is not to separate the artists from the art, but to consider the multitudes people are capable of.

reviews.name: Manohla Dargis
reviews.message: It shouldn’t work and, even after seeing it twice, I don’t think that it entirely does, which only makes it more fascinating and strengthens its power.

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: Master Gardener is among Paul Schrader's very best films. It’s also uncommonly optimistic – not that you’d know it right away.

reviews.name: Josh Kupecki
reviews.message: What Schrader has crafted with Master Gardener is a fable of redemption.

reviews.name: Michael Phillips
reviews.message: Even when it falters, Master Gardener speaks from a place the filmmaker has always worked, with one foot in the character-building of "slow cinema," and the other in spasms of violence.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: Edgerton is terrific, and while he does what he can with his expertly named character, Narvel Roth, the audience is required to take too many leaps to get behind this guy, while Schrader opens up doors he is simply not showing he’s equipped to handle.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: Master Gardener is mostly wrongheaded in placing the weight of redemption on the wrong character's shoulders.

reviews.name: Barry Hertz
reviews.message: A complex and layered thing that is sturdily resistant to quick, dirty, in-and-out discourse.

reviews.name: Richard Crouse
reviews.message: Master Gardener observes racism and redemption, wondering aloud if emancipation from the stigma of past deeds is possible.

reviews.name: Matt Conway
reviews.message: Master Gardener loses itself in the weeds of its thorny subject matter.

title: Robots
description: Charles is a womanizer while Elaine is a gold-digger. The duo learn humanity when forced to team up and pursue robot doubles of themselves.

characteristics.Producer:: Cassian Elwes, Julien Favre, Stephen Hamel, Lars Sylvest

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: As the contrivances go up, the laughs go down in this romantic comedy with a science-fiction twist, and a potentially amusing premise is squandered along the way.

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: Christensen and Hines don’t have a vision for cinematic silliness, creating a terrible episode of television instead.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: [T]he movie is mostly defined by its lack of insight, foresight, and any ability to see how poorly imagined and executed the attempted humor here is.

reviews.name: Carla Hay
reviews.message: Robots with artificial intelligence could have come up with a better movie than the filmmakers responsible for the drab and unfunny comedy Robots, an embarrassing dud that fails to blend sci-fi and romance into an interesting story.

title: Moon Garden
description: When a little girl has a terrible accident and slips into a coma, she finds herself thrust into a darkly surreal industrial dreamworld. Haunted by a nightmarish spectre that feeds off her tears, she must follow her mother's radio-static voice to find her way back to consciousness. Shot on expired 35mm film stock with vintage rehoused lenses, MOON GARDEN is a fantastical odyssey and a visionary, handcrafted, and fully practical work of art that shows how a child can shine light even in the darkest places.

characteristics.Producer:: John Michael Elfers

reviews.name: Daniel Gorman
reviews.message: Harris gets a lot of mileage out of his simple, lo-fi setup [but] one can’t help but wish Harris was more influenced by the actual weirdness of a Jodorowsky or the Czech New Wave instead of a pale imitator like Terry Gilliam.

reviews.name: Felix Vasquez Jr.
reviews.message: An absolute masterpiece...

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: A horror/fantasy that puts every bit of its imagination on the screen and constantly impresses with its DIY spectacle.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Although its dazzling eye candy tends to overshadow the thin narrative, this dark fantasy about childhood innocence and imagination remains compelling.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: So, while visually gorgeous in its commendable, if incomplete, message about the power of "healing", the smiles at the end feel more like resignation to me.

reviews.name: Amy Nicholson
reviews.message: Initially, we’re repelled by the ’90s grunge video aesthetics. Later, we admire the power in these visceral expressions of traumas Emma will someday tell her therapist.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: It's a creative, unsettling, and heartfelt film, made with obvious passion and an admirable sense of do-it-yourself craft.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: With Harris’ direction, the horror odyssey showcases pure visual creativity and genuine horror bonafides in its trippy world.

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: A surreal, visually dazzling and creepy experience, but concurrently exhausting and tedious with excessive style over substance.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: Ryan Stevens Harris’ Moon Garden invites viewers to explore not only another world but a very different perspective.

reviews.name: Kyle Logan
reviews.message: Does a fantastic job creating a novel world that combines stop motion, forward and backward moving timelapses, and paper cut-out animation with a simple, but incredibly effective monster, as well as sets that are just as beautiful as they are frightening.

reviews.name: Sharai Bohannon
reviews.message: Moon Garden is a fun ride that makes it easy to love. It’s equal parts rockabilly, heart, and wonder. It’s a feast for the eyes.

reviews.name: Rob Aldam
reviews.message: An unusual and disturbing childhood fantasy horror film

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Whilst Moon Garden’s visuals incite nightmares, the emotional weight hits like a sledgehammer. The combination ensure a film that will linger. Mad God with a pounding, bleeding emotional heart, Moon Garden is an unforgettable experience.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Ryan Stevens Harris’ fantasy fugue follows a five-year-old’s adventures in comaland on her way back to a fragile family

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A visually stunning fantasy film

reviews.name: Loren King
reviews.message: Trauma though a child’s vivid imagination, where memories, joy and fear meld into fantastical, often terrifying, imagery, is the heart of  the visually stunning Moon Garden.

reviews.name: Luke Y. Thompson
reviews.message: It feels at times like watching a magic show – you sort of think you might know how the trick was done, but then it pulls out a new angle and you’re pleasantly stumped.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: A dazzling use of various effects and animation techniques to tell a child's-eye-view story of purgatory, or something awfully close to it.

title: The Night of the 12th
description: In nearly every police precinct, detectives are inevitably confronted with a case that goes unsolved. The more heinous the crime, the more it haunts those whose duty it is solve it. Such is the dilemma for Yohan Vivès--a young, recently promoted police Captain--when he begins investigating the gruesome murder of a young women named Clara in the town of Grenoble. It's clear that the attack was pre-meditated, and the violent nature of the crime suggests revenge. Vivés' team methodically digs through the details of Clara's life, uncovering her secrets in hopes of weeding out the killer. Certain their suspect is a scorned ex-lover, Vivés is confronted with another, more complicated question: which one? Based on a true crime book by Pauline Guéna, The Night of the 12th is a gritty mystery that's "both highly effective and brilliantly acted, where procedures and mindsets reveal a frayed society" (Cineuropa), posing uneasy questions about the male-dominated world of law enforcement, and their ability to handle the violent crimes routinely perpetrated against women victims.

characteristics.Producer:: Caroline Benjo, Barbara Letellier, Carole Scotta, Simon Arnal
characteristics.Production Co:: Centre National du Cinéma et de L'image Animée, VOO, Cinéventure 7, Haut et Court, Canal+, Cinécap 5, Cinémage 16, Auvergne Rhône-Alpes Cinéma, Centre du Cinéma et de l'Audiovisuel de la Fédération Wallonie-Bruxelles, RTBF, Wallimage, BE TV, O'Brother Distribution, Tax Shelter du Gouvernement Fédéral Belge, Région Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes, Versus Production, Radio Télévision Belge Francophone, Doco Digital, Proximus, Ciné+

reviews.name: Sheila O'Malley
reviews.message: There's more going on here than meets the eye.

reviews.name: Bobby LePire
reviews.message: The cast perfectly plays their well-written roles, while the dialogue sounds authentic.

reviews.name: Bilge Ebiri
reviews.message: Its real-world mysteries eventually become existential ones, but the film never stops sending chills up your spine.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: This police procedural isn't therefore about justice or heroism or even violence. At least not any one isolated from the others. It's a look at the human condition and its tragic flirtation with futility.

reviews.name: Morgan Rojas
reviews.message: Composer Olivier Margueri’s score offers a beautiful mix of buoyancy sprinkled with melancholy, giving the film its ominous nature.

reviews.name: Ethan Vestby
reviews.message: It’s almost bold of director Dominik Moll and screenwriter Gilles Marchand to center their film so much around both the male perspective and flawed, albeit noble cop protagonists, and intriguing how Night of the 12th flips this on its head.

reviews.name: Nicolas Rapold
reviews.message: This is a refreshingly grounded, deceptively plain picture of crime-fighting as a grind of false leads, workplace fatigue and no closure.

reviews.name: John Powers
reviews.message: Focusing on a single, real-life murder investigation she covers, Moll has created a film that keeps looking like the conventional police procedural that it actually isn't.

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: Spellbinding and engrossing. One of the best psychological crime thrillers since Zodiac and No Country for Old Men.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Though the criminal act was lurid the film wasn't.

reviews.name: Owen Gleiberman
reviews.message: “The Night of the 12th” is a mostly compelling sit, though what lends the film its singular texture is that it keeps tricking us into thinking it’s a more conventional thriller than it is.

reviews.name: Monica Reid
reviews.message: The Night of the 12th goes deeper than the crime in question, delving into questions of violence, guilt, and the nature of evil.

reviews.name: Ruben Peralta Rigaud
reviews.message: An excellent film for the genre, guided by a convincing cast while being a beautiful and rare homage to the labor of political justice.  [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Ruth Maramis
reviews.message: An engrossing, multi-layered film that astutely delves into the psyche of the people trying to solve the case. Definitely not your typical by-the-numbers crime drama.

reviews.name: Paul Whitington
reviews.message: Dominik Moll’s eerily quiet film focuses on the impact violent crime has on those who investigate it.

reviews.name: Jonathan Coe
reviews.message: There is no doubting the grim authenticity of all of this. But that authenticity is sometimes at odds with the craftsmanship on display in the film’s several chilling suspense sequences and long, well-paced interrogation scenes.

reviews.name: Terry Staunton
reviews.message: Bouillon flits convincingly between charismatic and awkward as the cop facing his own dark night of the soul, and there's solid support from Bouli Lanners as Marceau.

reviews.name: Edward Porter
reviews.message: It’s a bit too frustrating for its own good, but its detailed, perceptive account still has a strong grip.

reviews.name: Dustin Chang
reviews.message: Gilles Marchant and Dominik Moll, the writer-director team known for tight Hichcockian psychological thrillers over the years, come with The Night of the 12th. It's a policier in the same vein as Memories of Murder and Zodiac.

reviews.name: Harry Guerin
reviews.message: This is an iron-grip film from minute one, an unbearably tense procedural that is punctuated by outbursts of anger and moments of achingly sad candour.

reviews.name: Hilary A White
reviews.message: Director and co-writer Dominik Moll uses controlled pacing and the jutting Alpine backdrop to give this excellent thriller the space to burn slowly but purposefully.

reviews.name: Helen O'Hara
reviews.message: The long and devastating fallout from a senseless act of violence affects almost everyone in this compelling reality-inspired account, which lingers in the mind in a way that few crime stories do.

reviews.name: Saskia Lloyd Gaiger
reviews.message: Not revolutionary, but competent and compelling.

reviews.name: Peter Bradshaw
reviews.message: A brutally engrossing drama.

reviews.name: Yasmin Omar
reviews.message: The film offers plenty of insight into masculinity: the anger, the posturing, the coarseness.

reviews.name: Amber Wilkinson
reviews.message: While a specific killer may not be unmasked, toxic masculinity and its co-conspirator the patriarchal society stand in the dock - and the case against them is damning.

reviews.name: Pablo De Vita
reviews.message: ... An intelligent, precise, and captivating thriller. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Paul Risker
reviews.message: French true crime adaptation The Night of the 12th (La nuit du 12) is a response to the fraught relationship between men and women, and the detective as metaphor.

reviews.name: Adrián Monserrat
reviews.message: Metaphoric and powerful... [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Diego Batlle
reviews.message: A film that's as valuable as it's fascinating. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Dominik Moll’s police procedural runs circles around the misogyny entrenched in patriarchal society.

reviews.name: Chris Barsanti
reviews.message: The film wants for deeper characterizations or a closer detailing of criminal procedure.

reviews.name: John McDonald
reviews.message: As the story progresses, we feel chilled by the things a group of apparently ordinary men take for granted.

reviews.name: James Croot
reviews.message: A surprisingly thought-provoking tale that will stay with you for days afterwards.

reviews.name: David Stratton
reviews.message: A deeply disturbing police procedural, based on a real-life unsolved case.

reviews.name: Sarah Ward
reviews.message: The Night of the 12th is a feature to sleuth along with, as Moll's second whodunnit in a row, but it's also a picture to sink into as its stark truths inhabit everything seen and heard.

reviews.name: Jim Schembri
reviews.message: Regrettably, the direction by Dominik Moll can’t sustain much tension in this so-so French-Belgian crime drama.

reviews.name: Paul Byrnes
reviews.message: The grandeur of the film comes from the depth of emotion. These may be the hard-boiled characters, but they are still human.

reviews.name: Simon Miraudo
reviews.message: It maybe puts too fine (or blunt) a point on it, but this is a very moral and compelling procedural with something powerful to say.

reviews.name: Andiee Paviour
reviews.message: Unanswered questions are spine and subtext in the murder of a woman who hid in plain sight.

title: The Cow Who Sang a Song Into the Future
description: When thousands of fish die in a polluted river in southern Chile, Magdalena, a woman long-deceased, emerges amongst their lifeless bodies. Magdalena encounters her widowed husband, sending him into a state of shock and prompting the return of their daughter, Cecilia. Magdalena's presence and her effect on the environment stirs curiosity and fear among her family. As the past comes into focus, mother and daughter are met with the opportunity to change the future.

characteristics.Producer:: Tom Dercourt, Alejandra García
characteristics.Writer:: Francisca Alegría, Fernanda Urrejola, Manuela Infante
characteristics.Production Co:: Bord Cadre Films, Dialectic, Sovereign Films, Whitewater Films, Wood Producciones, Das Kleine Fernsehspiel, Cinéma Defacto, Match Factory Productions, Jirafa films

reviews.name: Esmé Holden
reviews.message: In the presence of these limiting factors, however, The Cow Who Sang ultimately resolves as a less curious film than most of its runtime suggests.

reviews.name: Christy Lemire
reviews.message: "The Cow Who Sang a Song into the Future” might be too slow of a slow burn—and there’s not much to [its] characters beyond a few barely sketched traits.

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: Ambitious if unfocused, this transfixing Chilean eco-fable infuses magical realism into a haunting story of grief and fractured family dynamics.

reviews.name: Dan Bayer
reviews.message: The images, the score, and the performances are so alluring that it's impossible to look away from them. Given its uniqueness, it's also impossible to forget.

reviews.name: Manuel Betancourt
reviews.message: An idiosyncratic proposition from the start, Alegría’s debut is a wonder precisely because, even as it borrows bits of genre pieces from here and there, the film firmly cements its director as a distinctive voice in Chilean cinema.

reviews.name: Brandon Yu
reviews.message: The power of Alegría’s feature debut is found not in dialogue or explication, but in the lyrical, magical realist qualities of folklore: disappointed mothers and fathers, sacred animals and cursed rivers, love and forgiveness.

reviews.name: William Repass
reviews.message: The film is an object lesson in what can result when a work of art subordinates itself to a message.

reviews.name: Gary M. Kramer
reviews.message: An interesting blend of magical realism and social realism. The messages may be obfuscated but they are also intriguing and heartfelt.

reviews.name: Alexandra Heller-Nicholas
reviews.message: With The Cow Who Sang a Song Into the Future, Alegria marks her confident feature debut, crafting a tale as strange as it is memorable.

reviews.name: Kristy Strouse
reviews.message: The Cow Who Sang A Song Into The Future is a meditative and inventive addition that is as wistful as it is optimistic.

reviews.name: David Parkinson
reviews.message: The overall message is potent, while the sequences of the cows singing and the calves offering nuzzling consolation are deeply moving.

reviews.name: Nick Hasted
reviews.message: Alienatingly odd at first, The Cow Who Sang a Song into the Future is ultimately redemptive.

reviews.name: Edward Porter
reviews.message: For all its new-agey pretentiousness, however, this tale does have moments of strange and warm-spirited beauty.

reviews.name: Kevin Maher
reviews.message: It’s too slipshod to be serious, too earnest to entertain.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: The Cow Who Sang A Song Into The Future emerges as part of a growing body of work which is striving to address desperation with imagination, to find new ways to be.

reviews.name: Wendy Ide
reviews.message: Blending science fiction and magical realism, environmental catastrophe and family secrets, Francisca Alegría’s heady mystery is an ambitious and murkily atmospheric debut.

reviews.name: James Perkins
reviews.message: Chilean director Francisca Alegría brings us a gorgeous and heartbreaking family drama entwined with a powerful environmental message in The Cow Who Sang A Song Into The Future.

reviews.name: Cath Clarke
reviews.message: It’s a thoughtful film, tender, hopeful, with some knockout bovine performances too.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: This is not so much nature’s revenge as its renewal, in a film that, starting with a fecund river and ending in an arid desert, sings its weird lament for present loss and longing while still clinging vine-like to hope for future generations.

reviews.name: Raquel Stecher
reviews.message: This hauntingly beautiful Chilean fable reminds us that we are one with nature and we must protect it.

reviews.name: Josie Melendez
reviews.message: The epitome of Latin American storytelling. There is a lot of beauty and depth to it. The family dynamics alone make it very admirable.

reviews.name: Kathleen Sachs
reviews.message: Not surrealistic so much as it is magical realist in its consideration of ecological issues vis-à-vis its central narrative focused on a dysfunctional family.

reviews.name: Marya E. Gates
reviews.message: The Cow Who Sang A Song Into The Future reminds us we should go through life always thinking about how our choices will affect others, including the birds, the bees, and the fish in the seas.

reviews.name: Morgan Rojas
reviews.message: Francisca Alegra crafts a story rich in imagery and topical urgency in this bold feature debut. Its a lot to digest, but the payoff is completely worth it.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: When it comes to atmosphere and tone, it is hard to think of many other recent projects quite as successful as The Cow Who Sang A Song Into The Future.

reviews.name: Michael Frank
reviews.message: This feature debut represents a big swing for the Chilean director, a thoughtful, deliberate drama bursting with ecological and personal imagery.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Well-produced and enjoyable arty fable.

reviews.name: Alissa Wilkinson
reviews.message: The Cow Who Sang a Song Into the Future is mysterious and elegiac, a tale of warning about a collapsing ecosystem and about deep family wounds.

reviews.name: Pat Mullen
reviews.message: Reminiscent of Apichatpong Weerasethakul's Uncle Boonmee Who Can Recall His Past Lives in its enigmatic episodic-ness, The Cow Who Sang a Song ... is ultimately a film that washes over and envelopes a viewer like the waters of the early frames.

reviews.name: Jonathan Holland
reviews.message: Solidly grounded, teeming with thought-provoking ideas, wonderfully atmospheric, and often visually striking...

reviews.name: Ricardo Gallegos
reviews.message: Environmental poetry that dives into the sea of magical realism to create a captivating experience with a beautiful and urgent message. [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: Francisca Alegria's transfixing magical realist drama offers nothing if not a unique vision through which to examine grief for both family and our polluted Earth.

reviews.name: Rob Aldam
reviews.message: Urging the viewer to not dwell on the past but concentrate on making it a brighter tomorrow.

reviews.name: Rafael Motamayor
reviews.message: Thankfully, Francisca Alegría's feature debut manages to be hauntingly moving and hopeful instead of angry and pessimistic.

reviews.name: Drew Gregory
reviews.message: I have a high tolerance for languidly paced art films, but it's a rare treat to watch a film that's deliberate, enigmatic, and easy to recommend. Even if you're not sure what's happening, Alegria's film never loses your focus.

reviews.name: Caitlin Quinlan
reviews.message: An interesting example of climate-conscious cinema, if a little too abstract at times.

title: Stay Awake
description: A quietly powerful look at the ripple effects of opioid addiction, STAY AWAKE explores addiction from the lesser-seen viewpoint of the caretakers--in this case teenaged brothers Oleff and Argus. Their mother, played by Metz, is loving and well-meaning but powerless to pull herself out of the destructive cycle of her disease. The boys must put their dreams on the backburner as they're constantly discovering their mom passed out, dragging her to the hospital, and encouraging to go to rehab--with the possibility of relapse always lingering. Anchored by three superb performances, STAY AWAKE finds surprising humor and humanity amid the tragedy of parental addiction.

characteristics.Producer:: David Ariniello, Shrihari Sathe, Eric Schultz, Kelly Thomas

reviews.name: Matt Zoller Seitz
reviews.message: For the most part, "Stay Awake" stays low-key and believable, particularly when the actors move through real-world locations while living their lives.

reviews.name: Alton Williams
reviews.message: There are a number of flubs and missteps along the way, but there’s just enough character moments and pathos to help you stay awake.

reviews.name: Claire Shaffer
reviews.message: Oleff, Argus and Metz succeed in depicting both the frustrations and the compassion associated with caring for relatives who continuously harm themselves.

reviews.name: Avi Offer
reviews.message: An honest, wise and genuinely heartfelt slice-of-life with just the right balance of humor and heartbreak.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: A serious film on the dangers of drug addiction.

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: A situation and a story that will resonate with a lot of people

reviews.name: Clayton Dillard
reviews.message: Jamie Sisley’s film looks at its serious subject matter through a maudlin lens.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: Yet with strong performances and that nuance, Stay Awake surprises as a capable indie drama.

reviews.name: Laura Hiros
reviews.message: Sisley tells the story on a personal tone, showing how the drama goes hand to hand with humor, and how in  the most difficult moments, humans can get a connection beyond any limit. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Joanne Laurier
reviews.message: Competently made with affecting flashes, Stay Awake tends to be somewhat predictable and passive. As such, it does not break new ground. The filmmakers, however, should be given credit for tackling a social ill of enormous dimensions.

reviews.name: Dennis Harvey
reviews.message: Stay Awake is both tough and empathetic, a unsensationalized, realistic look at the difficulties of recovery in a society that frowns upon addiction, but doesn’t do much to help addicts become ex-addicts.

reviews.name: Ross Bonaime
reviews.message: Stay Awake is frequently honest and painful about this type of addiction in a way that is often jarring, but Sisley does so in a way that never feels suffocating, always ready with a lightness or glimmer of hope that balances the entire film beautifully.

reviews.name: Bill Arceneaux
reviews.message: One of the more fantastically told movies on the subject of addiction thats been made in recent times. Never overblown, always grounded when needed.

reviews.name: Benjamin Gummery
reviews.message: The film is wonderfully acted by the small cast that need to portray a range of complex emotions and the ebb and flow of relationships between characters. The rural setting of the film works perfectly and becomes a charecter in and of itself...

reviews.name: Tony Asankomah
reviews.message: It dares to tackle a known subject from a very unique perspective that is often overlooked and nails it whiles serving an emotional narrative.

reviews.name: Ronak Kotecha
reviews.message: 'Stay Awake' has its niche because of its subject, but if we look at the reality that we live in, it makes for a very relevant story. Sisley directs this film with great perspective on addiction and everyone affected by it.

reviews.name: Federico Furzan
reviews.message: A solid drama about often unrecognized role of caretakers in the world of opioid addiction. This is a greatly directed film.

reviews.name: Brittany Witherspoon
reviews.message: The reality about movies that portray drug dependency and abuse is that sometimes it works, and other times, it’s simply a way for filmmakers to heal from their trauma. For Stay Awake, it’s both.

reviews.name: Michael Szymanski
reviews.message: TVs This is Us star Chrissy Metz is not like youve ever seen her before. With this down-and-dirty role, she is deserving of any and all awards for braving this tough unpleasant, yet dramatic, role.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: Stay Awake is a film deserving of being known as a modern masterpiece.

reviews.name: Tony Macklin
reviews.message: Stay Awake has engaging actors, and is disquieting.

reviews.name: Shubhra Gupta
reviews.message: Stay Awake walks the tough tightrope between facile sympathy and over-romanticisation.

reviews.name: Alejandro Turdo
reviews.message: Stay Awake provides a different take on drug addiction and its collateral damage, enhancing its true event elements through a carefully put together narrative. A well crafted drama that may change people's perspective about this sort of issues.

reviews.name: Stephen Whitty
reviews.message: It’s a grim story but filmmaker Jamie Sisley – who admits he lived some of it, growing up – never gives in to despair.

reviews.name: Margrira
reviews.message: “Stay Awake” is a personal exploration of the horrors that families endure while trying to help their addicted loved ones with a disease that affects millions every day.

reviews.name: Evan Dossey
reviews.message: A strong addiction drama that succeeds thanks to excellent performances and characterization.

reviews.name: Emily Maskell
reviews.message: By the end, Sisleys film, with its teen angst under streetlights and nuances of addiction that refuse to be aestheticised, offers up a gentle handling of substance abuse that should be applauded.

reviews.name: Stephen Saito
reviews.message: A film that feels as if it moves a conversation around the toll of the overprescription of painkillers forward and the families stuck in limbo because of it.

reviews.name: Natalia Winkelman
reviews.message: A sensitive if not especially insightful family drama.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: Stay Awake is told from the boys' perspective and effectively allows them the complexity to move their frustrations to the forefront. It's natural for them to wonder aloud that something needs to give.

reviews.name: Taylor Baker
reviews.message: While the performances do exude that the characters believe their mother may die, the film itself doesnt indicate the stakes or truth of that melodramatic layer. The hospital scenes are sanitary

title: Outpost
description: An abused woman gets a job as a fire lookout in the mountains of northern Idaho, hoping the peaceful solitude will heal her trauma. However, the PTSD and isolation have other plans, and it's suddenly a fight to save herself and the town.

characteristics.Producer:: Kara Baker, Joe Lo Truglio, Joe Mortimer

reviews.name: Luke Gorham
reviews.message: There’s a whole lot of derivation of other works here... but very little to suggest a fully-formed vision from Truglio.

reviews.name: Crockett Houghton
reviews.message: The problem with Outpost is that it turned our survivor of something horrible into a murderer with no redeeming qualities. A swing and a miss.

reviews.name: Brian Tallerico
reviews.message: A film that’s too choppy and ridiculous for too long for its gut-punch of a final act to really connect.

reviews.name: Kimberley Elizabeth
reviews.message: [Outpost] ventures into the dark corners of the human psyche while delivering an unforgettable survival horror experience.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: It's difficult to imagine a less thoughtful and empathetic way to tell the underlying story of Outpost.

reviews.name: Aaron Neuwirth
reviews.message: While it’s of little surprise for me to once again see a comedic performer transfer their sense of tension and timing to the world of horror, I can say that I was ultimately won over thanks to having a cast full of character actors.

reviews.name: Carson Timar
reviews.message: While Outpost proves Joe Lo Truglio's ability within the horror genre and successfully overcomes many of the common faults in the genre, the film fails itself and its own characters with a beyond-questionable final act.

reviews.name: Brent McKnight
reviews.message: 'Outpost' has lofty aims and takes big swings. Though not all of them land and it never quite reaches the possible highs, this is a hell of a debut.

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: A little uneven, but Lo Truglio captures the mental quake of trauma reasonably well, getting the endeavor on its feet with some degree of success.

reviews.name: Melissa Hannon
reviews.message: While Outpost may tell a familiar tale of survival, this elevated indie is a solid entry in the psychological horror subgenre. Fans will always love (Joe Lo) Truglio for his comedic roles, but let's hope he has more horror up his sleeve.

reviews.name: Tim Brennan
reviews.message: The fact remains that Joe Lo Truglio is a new voice in horror, one that’s thoughtful when necessary and always committed to going for your guts.

reviews.name: Joel Harley
reviews.message: While the film never quite reaches the heights it aims for, this striking debut makes a solid platform for its director’s genre aspirations.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: ...an ordeal of endurance as much mental as physical, where victimhood is not just overcome but inverted. This is a glorious calling card – sensitive to sympathetic characterisation, yet unafraid, when the time is right, to call in the nasty exploitation

title: Dark Nature
description: While recovering from an abusive relationship, Joy joins her friend's therapy group on an isolated mountainous retreat. Led by a doctor with experimental methods, the group is soon forced to confront a monstrous entity.

characteristics.Producer:: Berkley Brady, Michael Peterson

reviews.name: David Nusair
reviews.message: ...a completely misguided endeavor that might’ve fared better as a short film (but even that seems unlikely).

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: I was too bored by its shallow search for answers to care what happens.

reviews.name: Marie Saadeh
reviews.message: Though the film shows some promise for Brady's future work, Dark Nature's attempts to make an affecting exploration of trauma — or at the very least give us a good scare — leave much to be desired.

reviews.name: Daniel Gorman
reviews.message: It’s an agreeable enough thriller that has unwisely cribbed from a beloved modern genre staple and simply can’t measure up to its predecessor.

reviews.name: C.H. Newell
reviews.message: Dark Nature is an authentic, fascinating exploration of trauma and the post-traumatic stress disorder that typically comes along with it, and it’s important that Berkley Brady, a Métis artist, is the director-writer behind it.

reviews.name: Sara Clements
reviews.message: The Métis director’s first horror feature is gripping from beginning to end and is anchored by a skilled female cast who captures trauma and PTSD in all its damaging, even deadly effects.

reviews.name: Rob Hunter
reviews.message: Dark Nature is ultimately a fairly straightforward tale of survival as Joy and the others fight against past wounds and present monsters, and while it doesn’t rewrite the subgenre it delivers where it counts with horrifying chills and survival thrills.

reviews.name: Sarah Musnicky
reviews.message: DARK NATURE is an uncomfortable watch. But it reminds us that if we want to heal from what haunts us, we must embrace the darkness.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: Brady knows the landscape well and makes effective use of it.

reviews.name: Christopher Cross
reviews.message: A creepy atmospheric psychological horror film that uses trauma like a bag of tricks but fails to reconcile its supernatural elements with the emotional struggles of its characters.

reviews.name: Kate Sánchez
reviews.message: If there is a movie this year that has made me want to crawl out of my skin, it’s [Dark Nature].

reviews.name: Joe Lipsett
reviews.message: Dark Nature skips over its most unique and intriguing elements...in order to get to the somewhat satisfying violent bits. [T]he film laid the groundwork for a deeper exploration of healing via female friendships and therapy that it fails to pay off.

reviews.name: Kat Hughes
reviews.message: Paranoia, trauma and the survival instinct are all explored in Dark Nature, a robust and anxiety-inducing debut from new voice Berkley Brady.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: ... by placing the creature up front, but, by doing so, it undercuts a far more interesting story regarding Joy, her trauma, and the consequences of not facing it sooner.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: And with a bit of a twist waiting in the wings, Joy's arc solidifies in a satisfactory way. So much so that it ensures the journey was worth our time despite also emphasizing how her companions might disagree.

reviews.name: Nikki Baughan
reviews.message: Its mix of spiritualism, survivalism and genuine scares make for solid entertainment.

reviews.name: Anton Bitel
reviews.message: Berkley Brady’s feature debut merges the natural, the supernatural and the psychological on an all-female trip into the wild

title: Come Out Fighting
description: Set during WWII, in this military adventure, a small, specialized squad of U.S. Army African American soldiers are sent on an unofficial rescue mission behind enemy lines to locate their missing commanding officer. The squad upon battling their way through the German defenses encounter more than they bargain for when they locate a downed U.S. Army fighter pilot. With the help of their friends at the 761st tank battalion, known as "The Black Panthers," the squad must find a way to survive and make it back in one piece.

characteristics.Producer:: Dean Bloxom, Andre Relis, Steven Luke
characteristics.Production Co:: Redbox Automated Retail, Lionsgate, Schuetzle Company Productions, VMI Worldwide

reviews.name: Mike McGranaghan
reviews.message: A movie about the contribution of African-Americans in WWII could be both important and stirring. Come Out Fighting is neither.

reviews.name: Julian Roman
reviews.message: Come Out Fighting has good intentions but struggles to be rousing and cinematic. Moments of genuine camaraderie are muddied by low-budget visual effects, questionable editing, and poorly defined, generic Nazi antagonists.

reviews.name: Calum Marsh
reviews.message: [Luke's] writing is thin and tends regularly toward platitudes, with characters spouting wisdom like “the cards have to fall where they fall.”

reviews.name: Brian Orndorf
reviews.message: It’s not all disappointing, as the feature shows some signs of life, but there’s a better, more stirring effort to be made about the subject.

title: The Thief Collector
description: It was one of the most audacious and puzzling art thefts of a generation; In 1985, Willem de Kooning's seminal work, "Woman Ochre," was sliced from it's frame and stolen from the walls of an Arizona art museum, disappearing into the desert. Over thirty years later, in a remote town in New Mexico, the $160 million dollar painting was rediscovered in the unlikeliest of places.

characteristics.Producer:: Caryn Capotosto, Jill Latiano, Joshua A. Kunau
characteristics.Production Co:: Roots Productions, Diamond Docs, Museum & Crane, XTR

reviews.name: Emily DuGranrut
reviews.message: Allison Otto’s The Thief Collector, then, is a most refreshing documentary that gives true crime the America’s Next Top Model moment it needs.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: The Thief Collector is wildly entertaining and features some of the funniest reenactments of the year.

reviews.name: Jared Mobarak
reviews.message: This is an utterly transfixing story told with an infectious tone, but it's about 80% speculation. And while that speculation is fun, the whole can feel like spinning wheels for long passages.

reviews.name: Mark Dujsik
reviews.message: [M]uch of Allison Otto's documentary ... amounts to a lot of speculation.

reviews.name: Mel Valentin
reviews.message: Ultimately, however, The Thief Collector confirms one of Citizen Kane’s grand themes, the unknowability of human personality. When the Sadlers left this world for the next, they took several, unrecoverable secrets with them.

reviews.name: Jordan Raup
reviews.message: With its whirlwind, surface-level observations of fascinatingly complex lives, it's the kind of scattershot true-crime documentary that grips in the moment but, with reflection, is more entertaining to discuss than revisit for additional clues.

reviews.name: Noel Murray
reviews.message: Allison Otto’s snappy documentary “The Thief Collector” ponders how and why the Alters got away with their one famous crime — and perhaps many more.

reviews.name: Liz Whittemore
reviews.message: Allison Otto brings audiences one of the most audacious modern-day stories of crime and passion. Part art history, part true crime, all intrigue, The Thief Collector is tailor-made for mystery lovers and cinephiles alike

reviews.name: Sherin Nicole
reviews.message: The Alters could rival Audrey Hepburn and Peter O’Toole in How to Steal a Million. After all, they did it. They got away with it too (but you’re not going to believe how).

reviews.name: Pam Grady
reviews.message: Out of a brazen act of theft, filmmaker Allison Otto fashions an indelible, all-American tale of life, larceny, and the pursuit of adventure,

reviews.name: Loren King
reviews.message: The Collector Thief is one of the most bizarre and intriguing of stranger-than-fiction documentaries, combining art heist and double lives.  It turns creepily pitch black and more incredulous than the most Coen of Coen brothers movies.

reviews.name: Leslie Combemale
reviews.message: Allison Otto’s doc goes unexpected places, far beyond a simple examination of one stolen masterpiece. This documentary reminds viewers the fun folks next door may be way more than they seem.

reviews.name: Jennifer Merin
reviews.message: The true story is astonishing, and Allison Otto’s take on it entails introduction of all the quirky characters, their psychological profiles, crime thriller plot twists and solid art history. The Thief Collector is solid entertainment.

reviews.name: Betsy Bozdech
reviews.message: The Alters’ story takes some unexpectedly dark turns, but overall The Thief Collector is breezy and fun.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: What begins as a spirited romp goes to dark places before it’s done

reviews.name: Todd Jorgenson
reviews.message: ... compiles a fascinating glimpse into broader notions of art appreciation and the peculiarities of human nature.

reviews.name: Cath Clarke
reviews.message: If nothing else, this documentary ought to give someone working in television the idea of making a detective series about house clearance experts.

reviews.name: Dennis Schwartz
reviews.message: Unusually interesting film, even if it has nothing to say that is definitive about the theft.

reviews.name: Warren Cantrell
reviews.message: Although it might have been nice to dig deeper  for example, a more thorough investigation into the Alter children  Otto and "The Thief Collector" seem to understand that an absence of answers is what makes this particular story so interesting.

reviews.name: Owen Gleiberman
reviews.message: A movie that has used art to touch something essential about how strangers — or maybe I should just say the downright strange — walk among us.

reviews.name: Allison Shoemaker
reviews.message: An entertaining and surprisingly suspenseful story of art, compulsion, chance and audacity.

reviews.name: Rachel Wagner
reviews.message: Otto keeps things light and fun. I particularly enjoyed the intentionally campy reenactments

reviews.name: Kent Turner
reviews.message: This tantalizing documentary abounds with theories and rationales for the Alters' actions.

reviews.name: Shaun Munro
reviews.message: While not fully exploiting its stranger-than-fiction story, The Thief Collector is a documentary as entertaining as it is odd.

reviews.name: Therese Lacson
reviews.message: While The Thief Collector is certainly an interesting tale and outrageous when you consider how easy it is to steal a painting from an artist as beloved as de Kooning, there's not a lot beyond the anecdote.
reviews.full_review: While The Thief Collector is certainly an interesting tale and outrageous when you consider how easy it is to steal a painting from an artist as beloved as de Kooning, there's not a lot beyond the anecdote.

reviews.name: Nick Allen
reviews.message: It says a lot more about how ravenous we are for true-crime story than it does the Alters, and tests whether were still interested if all we can get is a shrug.

reviews.name: Louisa Moore
reviews.message: A wildly entertaining film about a 1980s art heist that features twists, turns, and exceptional storytelling. You couldnt ask for a better understanding of documentary film directing.

reviews.name: Josh Kupecki
reviews.message: Secret, double lives are always intriguing stories because, well, don’t we all have one, if just in our head?

reviews.name: Chris Evangelista
reviews.message: The story itself is too juicy to ignore, and there's a certain sweetness layered throughout.

reviews.name: Douglas Davidson
reviews.message: Having its world premiere at SXSW 2022, what begins as a story about a painting theft turns into an almost existential crisis as truth and fiction blend together until one is unsure where either begins or ends.

reviews.name: Alex Saveliev
reviews.message: As an examination of art and the mysterious things that lurk in all of our heads, The Thief Collector does a splendid job, demonstrating how we truly never really know each other’s capabilities.

reviews.name: Nathaniel Muir
reviews.message: Character driven true crime documentary about one of the most audacious art heists ever. Once the story shifts from the actual crime to those who may have committed it, things get really interesting.

title: Black Lotus
description: A soldier uses his military training to rescue the kidnapped daughter of his dead friend.

characteristics.Producer:: Marcel De Block, Tom de Mol, Christian Mercuri
characteristics.Production Co:: Interstellar Pictures, Capstone Film Group, TDMP Tom de Mol Producties, Black Lotus Europe

title: White Building
description: 20-year-old Samnang and two of his friends live in the White Building, a landmark tenement in Phnom Penh. In this fast-changing city, the three boys practice their dance routine dreaming of television talent contests while their parents lead a more traditional lifestyle. But the White Building is to be demolished. Samnang observes his father unsuccessfully attempting to bring together his divided neighbors on the government's compensation offers for residents to move out, and he must face his best friend's departure from Cambodia. Samnang finds that the stable environment he has always called home is on shaky ground.

characteristics.Producer:: Davy Chou, Marine Arrighi de Casanova
characteristics.Production Co:: Doha Film Institute, Kongchak Pictures, Anti-Archive, Xstream Pictures, Apsara Films, CNC Aide aux cinémas du monde - Institut Français

reviews.name: Austin Considine
reviews.message: The film’s loose plotting and secondary character development can leave a few too many hanging threads, but its sense of place is so palpable you can almost smell the smoky city markets, the sweat, the hormones.

reviews.name: Dustin Chang
reviews.message: Contemplative and full of longing ... White Building serves not only as the filmic record of lives from the not-so-distant past but also reflects upon youth and their resilience and optimism in the face of change.

reviews.name: Alistair Ryder
reviews.message: This critique of gentrification largely remains implicit, visible only allegorically through their daily struggles.

reviews.name: Ezequiel Boetti
reviews.message: ... Filmed with a realistic imprint that avoids the picturesque views on the working class and on adolescence, proof that behind it, there's a director who knows what he's doing. [Full review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Daniel Gorman
reviews.message: Still, despite some quibbles, this is a strong fiction feature debut for Neang ... White Building understands the plight of an increasingly modern world that is constantly leaving its most vulnerable denizens behind.

reviews.name: Derek Smith
reviews.message: The films depiction of life impacted by urban transformation conjures a palpable aura of entrapment and helplessness.

reviews.name: Cath Clarke
reviews.message: This is a gentle-going watch, understated – underpowered even – and sometimes a little drowsy. Still, it has real sensitivity and insight...

reviews.name: Jay Weissberg
reviews.message: Kavich Neangs depiction of a traditional society moving from the stasis of trauma to parasitic capitalism is palpably felt, but the film's fitful energy and sympathetic yet undynamic characters work against the audiences emotional investment.

reviews.name: Panos Kotzathanasis
reviews.message: "White Building" is a well shot (the production names include Jia Zhangke and Davy Chou), well-directed in its combination of drama and documentary aesthetics, and well-acted movie and in general, a very interesting title on a number of levels

reviews.name: Nathaniel Rogers
reviews.message: Though it's steeped in sobering reality, White Building also knows when to switch things up with an unsettling dream sequence or a colorful daydream just this side of life as Samnang knows it.

reviews.name: Ricardo Gallegos
reviews.message: Showcases interesting technical artistry and several glimpses of talent, but not all the pieces fit together... [Full Review in Spanish]

reviews.name: Nikki Baughan
reviews.message: While the film is contemplative, intimate and visually arresting, its deliberately slow pace lessens its dramatic impact.

reviews.name: Jessica Kiang
reviews.message: "White Building" is a slow-cinema eulogy for Phnom Penh's recent past, but it's in its livelier moments that Neang lays claim to the Cambodian art-house future.

title: It's Quieter in the Twilight
description: They watch the bright lights from a distance today. The headlines now go to big names with bigger bank accounts. But, they are comfortable in the quiet, it suits them. Yet this quirky team of brilliant engineers--like the Voyager spacecraft they pilot--are pushing the notion of true discovery, traveling among stars propelled only by dwindling sunlight. While the world has moved on to fancier ships and splashier front men--the celestial journey of the aging spacecraft transcends earthly boundaries--from rural South Korea, the Jim Crow South and the U.S./Mexico border to cement a joint commitment to the mission which has traveled the furthest in human history as the clock winds down.

characteristics.Producer:: Alissa Shapiro, Billy Miossi, Matt Reynolds

reviews.name: Roger Moore
reviews.message: Both an elegy and a film infused with a dewy-eyed optimism.

reviews.name: Alan French
reviews.message: Director Billy Miossi discovers the power of a few engineers and scientists coming together to finish their mission. It’s Quieter in the Twilight shines a light on the importance of creating and preserving institutional knowledge.

reviews.name: Jennie Kermode
reviews.message: Billy Miossi’s documentary is elevated by a wonderful eye for detail.

reviews.name: Alan Ng
reviews.message: A lot of technical information is unloaded upon the audience, but Miossi lays it out in digestible chunks.

reviews.name: Richard Whittaker
